document.text: Zack Elliott Cheatham, 82, of Evergreen hid Tuesday, July 4,19TB in Medferi Care Center inIA 6 hhucg HI Bora in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late James Hudson, and MoUy Evans Chetttham. R t v u a farmer and dealer in cattle and horses and member of the Virginia Horse Show Association. He is survived by his wife, Mayme Chocklett Cheatham a son, James Elliott Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. a daughter, Jeanne C. Stanley of Appomat tox two sisters, Annie C. Bingham of Lynchburg and Alice C. Babcock of Columbia. S.C. four grandchildren, Zack and Nan Cheatham of Clear water, Fla., and Bill and Jan Stanley of Appomattox, and a great-grandson, James Hudson Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. Harrisonburg.In the little hamlet ef Royal Run, Shenandoah county, a mother and her daughter were the brides in a double wedding. Miss B. Annie Smoots was wedded to John M. Pence, of Forestville, while her  mother, Mrs. Sarah C. Smoots, and j Thomas J. Estep, of Cootes Store,  Rockingham county, were married. The ceremony was performed at the j home of the brides mother and grand parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ananias Polk, j Rev, A. K. Beck was the officiating minister. Charlottesville.  The usual fall j meeting of the board of visitors of the University of Virginia was attended by the rector, Armistead C. Gordon, j of Staunton Daniel Harmon, of j Charlottesville W. H. White, of Rich- j mend W. Drewery, of Petersburg J. j K. M. Norton, of Alexandria George I 6. Shackelford, of Orange H. D. j Flood, of Appomattox, and John W. 1 Craddock, of Lynchburg. The visitors accepted the gift by the Peabody Ed- j ucation Board of 40,000 for the erec- j tion of a suitable building for a home j for the department of education. The gift was made on condition that the I university undertake to maintain such j a department at an expenditure of not less than 10,000 a year. President j Alderman and the medical faculty were empowered to make such regu- j latlons as may seem wise on account j of the rapid increase of the first-year i medical class and overtaxed facilities I of the medical laboratory. Five sc hoi- I arshlps carrying exemption from tui-  tion and one-half of the fees In the j academic department were awarded to f the live white high schools In the DSs- j triet of Columbia. Petersburg.The quickest criminal trial on record In this State occurred in the Corporation Court, of Peters burg, Friday. Four youthful highway men, ranging in age from 14 to 18 years, Charles C. Williams and James Davis, of Fort Worth, Tex., and Joseph L. Cary and J. L, Brown, of Denver, Col., held up and robbed, at the point of their pistols, Charles C. Brown, ol this city, getting his gold watch arid chain and 80 in money. This occur red Wednesday night. The youths were arrested In Weldon Thursday morning and brought hack at night. Friday morning they pleaded guilty In the police court. At noon they were indicted by the grand Jury, They pleaded guilty, on arraignment, elect ed to be tried by the court, and, In less than an hour had been sentenced, each to 12 years in the penitentiary. The boys bad lived in New York city for two years and left that city for a tour of the South a week ago. They were armed with six pistols and In their possession were found many watches, stickpins and Jewelry, the fruits of heir various robberies. A watch arid a stickpin belonging to Samuel T. Taylor, of Baltimore, who was held up and robbed in that city Sunday night, were recovered. A watch and chain belonging to A. W. Harmon, of Richmond, who was rob bed on Tuesday, were also recovered. document.text: World War I Veterans of Ap pomattox County met in the Leg ion Hall last Monday to com plete the new Appomattox Coun ty Barracks, Veterans of World War I of the USA. The following officers h ave been elected to serve during the remainder of this year and for the year 1964 George W. Wooldridge, Com mander, Herbert C. Pulliam, Quartermaster - Adjutant, Dean A. Pugh, Senior Vice Command er, and J. At-MarttpJunior Vice Commander. The Trustees are Allen C. Lucado, W. E. Layne, and J. P. Harvey. In addition to the above offic ers the following are charter members Judge Joel W. Flood, N. E. Wooldridge, W. C. Holder- man, Willis D. Inge, W. A. Owen, Albert J. Zatrow, Royal P. Har vey, Orville Gunter, G. Lewis Doss, and Frank Harvey. It was voted to hold the Char ter Membership roll open until the next meeting which will be held on Sunday, December 1st at 2 p.m. in the Legion Hall. All honorably discharged Veter ans of World War I are extended an invitation to submit their ap plication to any one of the above officers or members. W. Glenn Elliott, Virginia De partment Adjutant, Virginia Beqch, Virginia was present to conduct the meeting. It will be recalled by the older Veterans of the County that Elliott assist-

document.text: With many visitors, friends and members of the St. Luke Church, services there were well attended. Rev. McLaugh lin was in charge. Rev. Alvin Jones assisted him. The Adult Choir gave very - inspiring music. Rev. McLaughlin spoke from 2nd Timothy 1-12, subjecGFully Secured. He brought out that our only security is in God. This was well taken. The offering was good. A special prayer was offered for the ill ones of the community by Rev. Jones. Namely Mr. Henry Hamlette, Mr. Bolin Jones, Mrs. Edith Jones, Miss Samatha Marshall, Mrs. Esther Callaham, Mr. Collins Callaham, and Mrs. Ocie Elliott, who will enter the hospital today, Mon. for treatm ent. Also , we are concerned about a much respected friend of the St. Lukers, the Rév. R. Q. Lawing and Mrs. Willie Mae McLaugh lin. On Jan. 30 the Senior Citizens of St. Luke who do volunteer work at the Lynch burg Home and Hospital attended a surprise birthday party for Mrs. Lena Wood, who was 87 years old. She was so graceously surprised and so calmly accepted the -kindness she received a beautiful corsage and gifts from the staff and was recognized as the Sweetheart Of The Day.  The news staff took T.V. pictures of the occasion. It was shown on the 600 p.m. news and also the 1100 oclock news. Those on the screen were Mrs. Virginia Abbitt, Mrs. Louise Canada and others shown doing friendly acts for the patients. The Senior Citizens of - St. Luke really enjoy going up each Friday and doing volunteer work for. those patients, The St. Lukes Senior Choir will be observing its aimiver- sary Feb. 22. All are invited to attend. Churches are being invited. Please come and enjoy this musical program. The Maggie Claytor Senior Club will meet at the home of Mrs. Evatna Prophett Feb. 9. All are so thankful for the refreshing rain.  Jordan Baptist news

document.text: William S. Bill Slagle was elected President of the Appomattox County Chamber of Commerce at the Chamber directors meeting held Tuesday November 30th. Slagle was formerly Town Manager for Appomattox and is presently with Virginia Fibre as Community Relations Mana ger. He is a graduate of VPI and is a native of Appomattox. Slagle stated his hope of increasing the membership base for the Chamber of Commerce in 1977 and in working actively toward Cham ber of Commerce objectives in support of Appomattox Com munity. document.text: William Henry Lerner. 76. of 1508 Florida Ave., Lynchburg, died Wednesday. Nov. 3, 1976 at 330 p.m. at His residence after a long illness.  Born in Campbell County, he was a son of the late William Frederick and Elizabeth Daines Lerner. He was a retired employe of the Azar Storage Company and a member of Mount Olivet United Methodist Church. t He is survived by his wife, Mary Lula Brown Lerner five eons, William Lerner of Edgewater. Md., James Lerner pf Annapolis, Md., Clarence Lerner of West Palm Beach, j Fla., Wallace Lerner of Glenj Burnie, Md., and Russell j Lerner of Stevensville, Md. two daughters, Mrs. Mary Mitchell of Lynchburg and Mrs. j Edith Brooks, of Concord onej brother, Charlie Lerner of Lynchburg three sisters, Mrs. Mae Cunningham, Mrs. Pearl Elliott and Mrs. Margaret j Cardwell, all of Lynchburg, 26 j grandchildren and 17 great- , children. Funeral services were con ducted Friday at 3 p.m. from the Whitten Park Avenue Chapel by the Rev. Joseph T. Carson, Jr. and the Rev. Janies T, Wood. Interment was in Fort fill Memorial Park.

document.text: William Baxter Cheatham, 34, of Rt. 1, Appomattox died , Saturday as the result of injuries sustained in an auto accident. He was the husband of Mrs. Margaret Cheatham. Born in Campbell County, he was a son of Mrs. Mary Cox  Cheatham and the late Russel Cheatham. In addition to his mother and widow, he is survived by six stepdaughters, Mrs. Jannis Burns and Mrs. Dreametta Austin of Appomattox, Mrs. Armetta Carter of Brookneal, Linda Younger of Concord, and Mrs. Carnella Eubank and Ruby Younger of Lynchburg a stepson, Norman Younger of Appomattox three sisters, Mrs. Etta Hamlett of Newport News, Mrs. Mary Elliott of Brookneal and Mrs. Evelyn Stone of Hurt two brothers, Richard Cheatham of Concord and Elliott Cheatham of  Brookneal, and 10 grandchild ren. Funeral services were con ducted at 1 p.m. Wednesday at St. Lukes Baptist Church by the Rev. R. Q. Lawing with burial in the church cemetery. Carl B. Hutcherson Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: who attended were benefitted by the message. The church choir render ed special music. The offering for the day was very good. A special offering for the American Red Cross was asked for by Mrs. Theda Harris. The annual Womans Day program will be observed at the Mount Shi loh Baptist Church this Sunday at 3 P. M. The program is sponsored by the Willing Workers Club of the Church. Music will be furnished by a special ladies chorus. The public is invited to attend. Mrs. Mary Page will serve as misteress of ceremony. The pubile is invited to attend a special service at the Canaan Baptist Church this Sunday evening at 730. The Rev. F. D. Yates will be guest speaker. The service is sponsored for the benefit of the Ladies Club of the church. The young Mr. Curtis Elliott will have charge of the morning services at the Galilee Baptist Church this Sunday morning at 1130. The pub lic is invited to come out and hear him. The church choir will render special music. Dont forget the union services at the Promise Land Baptist Church on the fourth Sunday morning in this month at 1130. The service will in clude members from Galilee, Mount Shiloh and Promise Land. Music will be rendered by a mixed choir of the three churches. Miss Margaret Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willie Harvey, of Spout Spring is improving after undergoing special treatment in the Lynchburg General Hospital. All churches in Appomattox Coun ty are asked to take a special of fering for the local Red Cross. Please respond to this Worthy cause. You are asked to give as much as you can in the name of your church. Each church name will be publish ed in this column with the amount given. Workers have been appoint ed in each church community. Area 11 of the Agricultural Teachers Association of Virginia met in the local Agricultural class room here last Monday at 6 P. M. Over forty teachers and supervisors were present. A group meeting with county agents was held here also at 230. Mr. Ross Newsome, of the State Extension Service, presided. The meeting was very informative. Mr. Anderson of the Lynchburg Chamber of Commerce was the guest speaker. The meeting was in the in terest of the junior hog show spon sored by the Extension and Voca tional Agricultural Services. Mr.- and Mrs. Leon Lawing spent the week-end in Petersburg, Va.  as the guests of his aunt and friends

document.text: White-Hall. The tabernacle meeting is now iu progress. The Rev. Mr. Traynham preached on Sunday morning and afternoon to an immense congrega tion. Rev. Mr. Stiff, of Lynchburg, and Rev. C. R. James, formerly ou this circuit, are expected to-day Monday. - Miss Watsie Elliott, to the delight of her many friends, has returned to her home, after a long visit to friends in Prince Edward and Ap pomattox. Miss Letts Elliott, her sister from Roanoke, is now with her. There are many other visitors iu the village. The political pot is boiling. The friends of Mr. W. P. Ellis are con fident that he vrill win out without doubt iu hi? race for the Senate. The Republicans of this couuty are urging Mi?.- E. D. Gregory, of this place, toV become a candidate for the Legislature. The recent rains have done some damage tothC tobacco orop. document.text: White-Hall. After long-continued Lot and dry weather, the rain came to-day, and farmers and everybody are refreshed and thankful. The tabernacle meeting closed on Tuesday night. An immense crowd was in attendance at the closing ex ercises. Rev. L. P. Bransford made a most earnest appeal to the uneon- erted, and many professed conyei- tion. Then, as Miss Watsie Elliott and Miss Bransford, with delicate toucii ou organ and piano, gave the note, the people sang- God be with you till we meet again, and thus closed the great ten-days meeting at White-Hall. Pt-jfessor Boatwright, president of Richmond College, was last week on a visit to his sister, Mrs. Clark. Dr. Wm. Broadtlus, of Richmond, and Mr. Frank Gayle, of Newport News, were the guests of Mr. P. H. Coghill while the meeting was in progress. Rev. C. P. Scott, the pastor, will begin a meeting at Maysvillc Bap tist Church, on the first Sunday in September. He will have assistance. Mr. Scott is a man of splendid at tainments, and a most gifted orator, and will attract large crowds. He always has large, attentive, and ap- pieciative congregations. The Ban- dsts at Maysville have completed a large, comfortable, and attractive- looking house of worship. They were generously aided by all of tbe other denominations. The church will be dedicated at the September meeting. On Saturday there was a consid erable windstorm at Arvouia. The large shop where slates are made by ihe Williams Slate Company was completely torn to pieces by the furious wind but, fortunately, the hands were not at woik, and no one was injured. Farmers say that the corn crop iu this section has been greatly injured by the long, hot, dry weather. The lobaceo will be greatly improved by the recent rain, and will make an average crop, as the rain came in time to save it.

document.text: While I live will I praise the Lord I will sing praises unto my God while I have any being. Psalm 1462 A large crowd attended our annual Homecoming Day Ser vices on last Sunday. Rev. C. L. Elliott and the Alabama Baptist Church Choir was in charge of morning service. At 230 p.m. the Gospel Harmonettes held dedication services for their robes. Taking part in this service were Rev. Douglas Carter, Rev. C. L. Elliott, and Mrs. Josephine Hall. Mrs. June Carter also took part in this service. Our speaker for the after noon was Rev. Douglas Carter, pastor of the First Baptist Church, of Burlington, Ohio. The Gospel Harmonettes fur nished music for this service. Rev. Carter is also our evangelist for the week. Prayer srvice begins at 730 p.m. with preaching service beginning at 8 p.m. Make plans now to attend for these last two nights. There will be a Quartette ,Sle8tival held here on.tke.5th Sunday in August act 780  On September 7th at 7 p.m. the Junior Choir will celebrate their anniversary. The following groups will be singing here on the 13th of Septem ber The Heavenly Five, The Echoes of Joy, The Gospel Crowns and the Spiritual Knights. Remember that Deacon Cris Austin is in the hospital. Pray for him and all of the sick and shutin, and for the sick and shutin everywhere. Have a Nice Day.

document.text: While engaged in cutting wheat Monday, George E. Elliott, of Hali fax county,accidentally mowed down and killed his little son, a bright little hoy about five years old. The child came up behind his father just in time for the scythe to strike him as it wasbeingswungaround to emp ty the grain. The blade struck him about theshort ribs and made an awful wound, from which death ensued almost instantly. The father I was frantic with grief.

Not with standing the hot dry weather and holiday and vacation time . a sizeable crowd attended the regular preaching services at St. Luke. Sun., July 6 at 1100 a.m. Rev. McLaughlin was in charge and Rev. Alvin Jones assisted in. the devotions. The Adult Choir gave the music. Mrs. Josephine Now lin was at the piano. Rev. McLaughlin spoke from Luke 1439-40. Subject- If you dont speak out and praise God, the rocks will. This was well taken. At the close Miss Joyce Elliott came forward and rededicat ed herself to the church. Then a prayer for the despondent ones of the church was offered by the pastor. The offering was good, the Sunday school lesson was good as taught, .by Rev. Jones. Miss Mary Hill, an out of town visitor for the holiday, stayed with her parents, Mr, and Mrs. Frank Hill and attended the church  ser vices. Also Mr. Roosevelt Callaham who was a visitor of his mother, Mrs. Esther Callaham attended the chur ch services. Also there was other visitors present at the service-Thespirifc warWgH? for the day. The pastor Rev. McLau ghlin and his wife - were leaving for New York Sunday night to attend the funeral services of his aunt who was around ,114 years of age. St. Luke is getting ready for homecoming and revival for Aug. 3. Rev. Earnest McLaughlin, brother th Rev. James the pastor of St. Luke will be the speaker for the afternoon services and carry on for the week. His choir will be in- charge for the Sunday p.m. music. All are invited to come. With activities all around for-the 5th Sunday a lovely crowd attended the BaDtist. Cornerstone Sunday School Union on that day at St. Andrews. President Venerable was in charge. Elliott at the Jordan Baptist Church last Sunday at 330 p.m. Mr. Elridge Hamlette is improving at his home after a recent sick spell. Mr. Henry Hamlette is still on the sick list. All interested persons are asked to. contact Mr. Tim Lawing concerning the bus trip to Union Baptist Church in Baltimore, Md. at their earliest convenience. Funeral services were held this past Friday for Mrs. Alice LeGrande.  A host of out-of- town relatives and friends attended the services.

document.text: We would like to thank everyone who came out on Saturday night to support the program sponsored by Miss Celia Mosley for the NAACP. The Star liners of Rustburg presented a lovely musical program. Everyone present also enjoy ed the program presented on Sunday night by the Holiness Singers and the Gospel Quintette for the benefit of the youth club. The program that was scheduled for Sunday night has been postponed until a later date. Beginning Wednesday, Oct. 20, there will be a series of services at the Jordan Baptist Church. Our guest for the week will be Wed - Rev.W. R. Jones  1st Baptist South Lynchburg Thursday - Rev. Roy Wood and Morning Star Friday - Rev. J. W. Paige and his mens chorus Saturday - Rev. C. W. Dunning and the Mt. Carmel Young Adult Choir. These services will begin at 745 p.m. each night with prayer service and preaching will be at 800. On Sunday Oct. 24, this series of services wfll come to a close at 300 p.m. Rev. Don Lewis and the St. John Gospel Chorus will be our guest. This will also be the close of our state rally. We urge our many friends to join us in these services. Rev. R. McCray will be our guest minister on the 4th Sunday morning at 1100 a.m. as Rev. Elliott is on vacation this month. On the 5th Sunday, October 31st, at 600 p.m. the Harps of Lion wfll celebrate their 5th anniversary at the Jordan Baptist Church. Many of your favorite groups will appear on the program, so plan now to attend. We are glad to report Mrs. Dorothy Fleshman is out and getting around after her stay in the hospital.

document.text: We know all things work together for good to them that love God. Romans 828 Mrs. Tommy Tanner is a patient at Lynchburg General Hospital. So glad to report Mr. Carey Carson was at Sunday School Sunday at Hebron. So glad to have him back. Mr. Will and Jack Harris spent the week end with their grandmother, Mrs. Nina Cald- well. Mr. and Mrs. A. F. Elliott, Jr., Mark and Scott got home Sunday afternoon after a three week visit to Hermit, Calif. They report a grand trip. Mr. and Mrs. J. P. Alvis, Jr. spent the week end with her family at Orange. The Roope family reported a hot trip in the Smokey Mountains. They got home Friday. Mrs. Eleanor Roach spent Sunday with her father, Mr. J. O.Davidson and unde, Craw ford. Mrs. Mary Barr ell came Monday for a weeks visit. Mrs. Hazel Gillespie is still with her sister in Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Hawks gave a fine sermon at Hebron Sunday.
